Variation Example: (The Burning of Lanka) Misc. type. A fool takes the instructions of a salesman (clergyman, doctor, his wife, etc.) literally & thus causes (suffers) damage or injury.

Classifications: The Company to Sing like the Leader
Variation Example: Two (drunken) men (married couple, a group of people) on their way home from a market day (wedding) try to sing together. The leader’s foot becomes caught in a wheel. He (she) cries for help, but no one understands; the cry is taken to be part of the song & is thus repeated by the group. Often the leader’s foot is broken before the wagon is stop ped. In a Berber variant, a teacher from the city is supposed to teach prayers from the Koran to men in the mountains. They stand out side & repeat the words of the prayers after him. The teacher bows to the ground & touches a board, which he is using to protect himself from the mud, with his forehead. His nose becomes wedged in the board. The teacher calls for help, but the companions take this for part of the prayer & repeat the words zealously. The teacher tears his nose away, leaving the tip behind. He tells the companions they must first learn Arabic, & departs.

Villagers (serfs) intend to wel-come (congratulate, honor) a visiting nobleman. The mayor leads the delegation, & the others are supposed to copy everything he does. (They each present a dish of food to the nobleman.) The leader stumbles & falls (spills the food on the table or on the floor), & the others do likewise. In his anger over the accident, the mayor curses, e.g. , “Go to the devil!” The others add, as they had rehearsed, “With your wife & children”, “and your aunts & uncles”, “and the noble lady, & the whole company!” In German & Austrian variants, the inhabitants cannot decide what to wear. When the visiting dignitary arrives, they hurry, still naked, to greet him. When the mayor is bitten on his backside by a horse-fly, he uses his hand to shoo it away, & all the others copy this gesture. In other variants, the reception goes wrong for other reasons.

A man (fool, Eulenspiegel) who works for a shoemaker is supposed to cut some leather for shoes. He asks his master, “How (big) should I make them?” & is told, “Big & small, just as the herdsman drives them through the gate”. The man makes shoes for pigs (sheep). When the master sees this, he throws the man out. Or, they take the shoes to market & tell customers that the winter will be so cold, even the animals will need shoes. The customers pay well for the shoes.

Misc. type. A mother tells her stupid son (man tells his wife) what he should have said (done) in a particular situation. The son follows the advice at the next opportunity, where it turns out to be inappropriate. He is punished (is told again what he should have done or said, & he follows that advice in the wrong circum-stances, etc.) For example, the fool congratulates mourners & offers sympathy to a bridal couple.

Three Valaisans (men of another nationality) who are going to England (another foreign country) learn in advance some important English phrases. The first one learns to state who they are: “We three Valaisans”. The second one learns how to convince a prospective landlord to give them food & lodging: “For the money”. The third one learns to agree to a stipulated price: “That’s right”. On their journey they are accused falsely of having committed a murder. The judge asks who committed the crime, & the first man answers, “We three Valaisans”. The judge asks why they did it, & the second man says, “For the money”. The judge condemns them to be hanged, & the third man responds, “That’s right”. The three men are hanged (or, the real culprit is found & the three men are freed).
Misc. type. Two (or more) people cannot understand each other because of their impaired hearing. Misunderstandings ensue.

One deaf person has lost sheep (other animals) and, while he is looking for them, meets another deaf person. Neither recognizes the other’s disability. A asks if B has seen his sheep. B misunderstands but gestures in a certain direction as he re plies about something else. A goes in that direction & finds his sheep. He thanks B & offers him one of his animals which is de form ed (lame, etc.) as a reward for his help. B thinks A is blaming him for the animal’s deformity. They fight. They take their argument to a judge, who, unknown to either of them, is also deaf. His judgment is absurd.

A master (priest) who has accidentally dirtied his finger with excrement demands that his servant cut it off (burn the dirt off). He sticks the finger through a hole & the servant strikes it with a burning piece of wood. The master is in so much pain that he pulls his finger out & puts it into his mouth to soothe it.

A traveler asks for directions, but a deaf man misunderstands & thinks that he is offering to buy his ox for a certain price. The traveler repeats his question & the deaf man refuses to sell his animal. His deaf mother brings his dinner. When he tells her about the traveler’s offer, she thinks he is telling her that the food is too salty. The daughter-in-law misunderstands what her mother-in-law says about the salty food, etc. The whole family is deaf & they all misunderstand each other.
The servant thinks that he will punish his master by refusing to eat.

Classifications: Two Persons Believe Each Other Deaf
Variation Example: A trickster tells each of two people (often women) before they meet that the other is deaf & must be shouted at. They do this, & each thinks that the other is insane. After a while, the trickster reveals his trick.

A landlord meets a deaf farmer & asks him how much he wants for the livestock he has with him. The farmer thinks he is being asked about his daughter’s wedding, & tells about this. The landlord asks if he may come, & the farmer replies with the price of the livestock. The landlord says that the farmer is crazy, but the farmer thinks he is wishing him well, & returns the good wish.

Classifications: Misunderstood Words Lead to Comic Results
Variation Example: Misc. type. A deaf person misunderstands similar-sounding words, which leads to unexpected (comic) results or dialog. In some cases, someone feigns deafness in order to avoid an obligation or some other unpleasant situation In others, a hearing person wants to make fun of a deaf person but is embarrassed by his answers.

Classifications: The Deaf Man in the Tree
Variation Example: A traveler asks the way of a man who is up in a tree, who happens to be deaf. The man in the tree keeps telling him about the bird he has caught (apples he has picked).

A deaf (hearing-impaired) man goes to visit a sick friend. He wants to hide his impediment so he plans a conversation with questions & answers. The resulting dialog is absurd: “How are you?” – “I am dead.”– “Thank God! What have you eaten?” – “Poison, I think.” – “I hope it agrees with you.”

A traveler (nobleman) greets (questions, insults) a deaf workman (farmer, fisherman), but the workman answers as if the traveler had meant to comment on his work. Often the workman had imagined what a potential interlocutor would say to him & had rehearsed his answers. Or, he pretends to be deaf because he is afraid that the traveler will ask him to do some thing he does not want to do (e.g. lend him something).

A deaf seller cannot understand what his customer asks him & gives inappropriate answers. The customer does not know about the man’s impairment & thinks he is insane. Often the seller has imagined what a potential customer would ask & has rehearsed his answers (has been given instructions about what to say).

A minister (priest) is called before the bishop because he has been accused of drinking too much. The bishop is old & deaf. The minister confesses his sins publicly in the church: “In the morning I have a drink” (spoken loudly), “and after that five or six little drinks” (spoken softly). “At noon I have another drink” (loudly), “and then five or six small ones” (softly). The bishop, who hears only the loud words, tells the congregation that the minister has the right to have a drink with his meals, & finds him innocent of the charges.

A man (farmer, farmhand, old man, woman) is asked to do something or is told something that he does not want to hear. He pretends to be deaf. But when something is said that he wants to hear, he can hear that.

Classifications: Misunderstanding Because of Ignorance of a Foreign Language
Variation Example: Misc. type. Two people who speak different languages cannot understand each other. One of them pronounces the words so that they seem to have a different meaning, or the words sound like different words in the other person’s language. Often an absurd conversation leads to unexpected events. In some variants the misunderstanding happens because one person does not understand a foreign word (technical term). Or an ambiguous message (statement) leads to the discovery of a criminal (planned crime).
New recruits learn answers to questions in a foreign language. When the order of the questions is changed, confusion ensues.

A traveler (apprentice) comes to a city in a foreign country (usually Amsterdam, but also Paris, Hamburg, Vienna, Moscow, etc.) where he sees a beau-tiful building (villa, palace, factory). Curious, he asks a passerby, “Whom does it belong to?” The passerby replies, “I can not understand you”, which the traveler misunderstands & takes to be the name of the owner. Similarly, he asks other people in turn the name of the husband of a beautiful woman, of the winner of the lottery, or the owner of a ship. He is amazed at the wealth of Mr. “I Cannot Understand You”. He becomes reconciled to his own modest circumstances when, as he follows a funeral procession, he learns that Mr. “I Cannot Understand You” has died.
A woman (man) asks an echo a question. The echo repeats the last phrase, which gives the (often unwelcome) answer.

Misc. type. Besides various single variants, two main versions of this story can be distinguished: (1) A stutterer (barber) is addressed by a stranger (student) who also stutters. He thinks the stranger is making fun of him, & a fight ensues. (2) A bride & groom will not talk to each other, because neither of them wants the other to know about his (her) stuttering.
Two taciturn farmers understand each other through half words.
Misc. type with diverse variants.
Misc. type with diverse variants.

A soldier who is quartered with a farmer demands food & lays his saber on the table to emphasize his order. The farmer brings a pitchfork & lays it beside the saber. The soldier asks what this is for, & the farmer explains that such a great knife warrants an equally great fork.

A man becomes alarmed by animals who speak. For example, he meets a dog who greets him, or he curses his ox & it replies to him. In North American variants, the man wants his horse to jump over a hole. The horse says, “I will not”. The man turns to his dog & says, “Isn’t that strange, a horse talking!” The dog says, “Yes, it is”. Often the man runs away, meeting other animals which answer him. In some variants, objects as well as animals speak.
Misc. type with diverse variants.

A hard-drinking man wagers a drink (piece of bread) with himself (someone else, his horse) that he will be able to pass by an inn without going in. He succeeds (because he throws away his purse by the door of the inn). He (picks up his purse) & goes back to the inn to reward himself for his will power with the promised drink.

Three (five) tipplers make a bet (with the inn-keeper) for a certain amount of alcohol that they will do whatever their wives ask of them. The first stumbles over a washtub (chair). His wife says, “Good, just fall into the tub (smash up the chair)!” He obeys. The second drops a pan (wakes the baby). “Throw everything around (wake all the children up)!” He obeys. The third stumbles. His wife says, “Go ahead, break your leg!” He does not obey & loses the bet. (He spills some sauce & she says, “Smear it all over the table!” He obeys.) The wife of the fourth man tells him to sleep all day in an empty cask, & he obeys. The wife of the fifth tells him to drink all the water in the pipes. He cannot, & loses the bet.
A drunken farmer comes home & cannot find his bed. He falls asleep in the pig sty, where he feels the sow’s belly & thinks it is his wife’s. He asks, “Are you wearing the jacket with 36 buttons?”

Classifications: How the Drunken Man was Cured
Variation Example: A wife cures her husband of his alcoholism by a ruse. When the husband is drunk, she organizes a funeral procession, lays him in a coffin & puts a shroud (fool’s costume) on him. When the drunk husband awakes he thinks he is dead. Later, believing that he has been revived by his wife, the man swears he will never drink any more. Or, a drunken man lies under the bed & thinks he is lying in his shroud. This cures him of his alcoholism. In some versions the drinker is uncurable. When his wife, dis-guised as a ghost, brings him food, he tells her, “If you had known me better you would have brought me drink”. The wife capitulates.

Miners (nobleman) take a drunken man (drunkard, tax collector, miser, broom maker) into the mine (into the castle of a nobleman). When he awakes he thinks he is in hell. The miners pretend to be devils. Only when he promises to reform do they allow him to go home.
A nobleman shoots the pipe out of the mouth of a commoner (Jester).

A young man (student) asks his father to send him a new pair of boots. The father tries to send them by telegraph, & throws them over a telegraph wire. A vagrant takes the boots & leaves his old ones in their place. The father thinks that his son had received the new ones & returned his old pair. In some variants, a fool (foolish woman) wants to send a package & a letter by telegraph. He hangs the package on the wire & reads the letter out loud.

A shoemaker (apprentice) is afraid of nothing. His friends want to test this & ask him to keep watch over a dead man. One of them pretends to be dead & lies (instead of a real corpse) in a cof-fin. During his watch, the shoemaker repairs some shoes. Suddenly the “dead” man begins to move (breathe). The shoemaker orders him to lie still. When the “dead” man moves again, the shoemaker says, “Whatever is dead must stay dead”. He hits the impostor on the head with his hammer & kills him.
A fine lady explains her ailment to her doctor in com plicated, poetic paraphrase. The doctor does not understand her. The lady’s servant explains briefly in vulgar language.
